title: 109_hr5172
content: The Act may be cited as the "Military Range Legacy Act of 2006" and includes a table of contents. The "Military Range Legacy Act of 2006" includes definitions, Department of Defense implementation requirements, wide-area assessment of suspected UXO sites, detection instrument technology research, Single Munitions Response Program, inventory, public database of incidents, Sense of Congress regarding munitions procurement, report on defense site cleanup, and Comptroller General study on military munitions response program. Comptroller General study on defense land management and transfer. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines terms related to unexploded ordnance, defense sites, discarded military munitions, and munitions constituents. SEC. 3. DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE IMPLEMENTATION OF REQUIREMENTS REGARDING UNEXPLODED ORDNANCE, DISCARDED MILITARY MUNITIONS, AND MUNITIONS CONSTITUENTS. The Congress urges the Secretary of Defense to promptly implement all requirements related to inventorying, characterization, remediation, and management of explosive risks at defense sites, as outlined in specific legislative acts. This includes conducting wide-area assessments of suspected unexploded ordnance sites. Section 2710 of title 10, United States Code, is amended to establish a wide-area assessment program for formerly used defense sites to identify areas free of unexploded ordnance and discarded military munitions. The program must be completed within five fiscal years of the Military Range Legacy Act of 2006 enactment. The wide-area assessment program for formerly used defense sites is authorized to receive $1 billion from 2007 to 2011. The Secretary must review the program's progress annually as part of the site-prioritization list. SEC. 5. DETECTION INSTRUMENT TECHNOLOGY RESEARCH. The Secretary is required to establish a research program for unexploded ordnance detection instrument technology in consultation with munitions developers. The program can be carried out through grants, contracts, or utilizing existing Federal agencies. Up to 10 percent of the total amount appropriated can be used for detecting Improvised Explosive Devices. Authorization of Appropriations.--$30,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2011 for research on unexploded ordnance detection technology. The funds can also be used for detecting improvised explosive devices. The Secretary will review obstacles to implementing new detection technologies and transferring them to private companies. The Secretary will review obstacles to implementing new detection technologies and transferring them to private companies, in consultation with appropriate private companies and Federal contracting agencies. A report describing efforts to improve technology transfer must be submitted to the appropriate congressional committees within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. SINGLE MUNITIONS RESPONSE PROGRAM. The Secretary of Defense shall establish a UXO Program Manager as the single point of contact for policy and budgeting issues related to military munitions response at defense sites. The program manager will report to the Assistant Deputy Under Secretary of Defense and establish an advisory panel with experts from various organizations. The Secretary of Defense established a UXO Program Manager as the point of contact for military munitions response at defense sites. The program manager will report to the Assistant Deputy Under Secretary of Defense and establish an advisory panel with experts from various organizations. The panel includes the Academy of Sciences, NGOs with expertise on unexploded ordnance, the EPA, States, and tribal governments. It will report annually to Congress on progress and make recommendations. The program manager is responsible for executing funds for ordnance remediation. The Secretary of Defense established a program element for remediation of unexploded ordnance and discarded military munitions within the Military Munitions Response Account. SEC. 7 amends Section 2710 of title 10, United States Code to develop and maintain an inventory of defense sites with unexploded ordnance. SEC. 8 establishes a public database for incidents involving unexploded ordnance or discarded military munitions. The Secretary is required to establish and maintain a public database of incidents involving unexploded ordnance or discarded military munitions since January 1, 1917. This database will include details of each incident and accident, sourced from Department of Defense and other Federal and State records, and media reports. The Secretary will provide the database of incidents involving unexploded ordnance to specified entities and the public in electronic and printed form. Congress urges military departments to consider full life-cycle costs of munitions in procurement decisions and review live-fire practices to reduce unexploded ordnance. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress outlining the strategy for completing environmental remediation of military installations approved for closure or realignment. The strategy must include consultation with local stakeholders and an estimate of necessary funds. Up to $1,000,000 is authorized for the Secretary to prepare for this task from the Department of Defense Base Closure Account 1990. The Secretary of Defense is authorized up to $1,000,000 from the Department of Defense Base Closure Account 1990 to prepare a report and strategy for completing environmental remediation of military installations approved for closure or realignment. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the adequacy of funding, staffing, and organization of the Military Munitions Response Program, including mechanisms for accountability and methods to reduce project timelines. A report of the study results must be submitted to Congress within one year. Additionally, another study will be conducted on defense land management and transfer. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the effectiveness of current procedures for managing and transferring former defense land. The study will assess the benefits and disadvantages of establishing a centralized Department of Defense office or a Federal Government Corporation for land disposition. Results of the study must be submitted to Congress and the Secretary within one year.
